Quantum mechanics is a mathematical theory that has been very successful in describing a wide range of phenomena. However, it is not a theory that is easy to understand. This is not because of any intrinsic difficulty of the theory, but because of the lack of a clear mathematical foundation. In this paper, we provide a mathematical foundation for quantum mechanics.

The evolution of parasites is a key topic in biology, and the study of the origin and evolution of parasites is of great interest to both the scientific community and the public. Here, we provide a comprehensive analysis of the genomes of two myxozoan species, which are among the most reduced animal parasites. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister taxon to the more complex polypoid cnidarians. In addition, we show that myxozoan genomes are among the smallest reported in animals and that they are highly reduced in gene content. These results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian.

The ability of viruses to evade host defense mechanisms is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and replicate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this activity and that it does so by directly binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex at the nuclear pore complex. This interaction prevents the docking of the karyopherin/importin complex, which is responsible for the nuclear import of the transcription factors. Our data provide a mechanism of viral antagonism that could be used by SARS-CoV-2 to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will affect the global food supply, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We use a statistical model to project the impact of climate change on maize yields in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores (LMH) partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savannas. However, the extent to which LMH partition food resources is largely unknown because species-level identification of food plants is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven LMH species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. Our results show that LMH are highly specialized in their consumption of grasses and nongrasses, and that species that are similar in body size and proportional grass consumption have the greatest overlap in their diets. These findings suggest that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results also suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of LMH in the maintenance of biodiversity in African savannas.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses are planning to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but they anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is a ubiquitous problem in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly because of the selective removal of small plastic fragments. This finding has important implications for the understanding of the impacts of plastic debris in the ocean.

We determined the age of a presolar silicon carbide grain extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grain has a lifetime of <300 Ma in the interstellar medium, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We also determined that the grain was part of an aggregate in the interstellar medium. The grain acquired the bulk of its cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in the striatum of a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of α-syn that is known to be neurotoxic. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. The endothelium is the single layer of cells that lines all blood vessels. It is the primary interface between the blood and the tissues of the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. It is also responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, the formation of clots, and the formation of clots. It is a highly specialized cell type that is constantly receiving information from multiple sources. This paper describes the nature of the communication system that the endothelium uses to integrate this information and to coordinate its responses.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. In this paper, we describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the pandemic and public behavior. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are designed to be useful for a wide range of applications, including epidemiological model development, public health surveillance, and research into the behavior and impact of the pandemic.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This structural coupling is mediated by an allosteric mechanism, which is triggered by the opening of the activation gate. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this Threonine residue is essential for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We also show that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. These results provide a structural basis for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in K+ channels. They also provide a structural basis for the development of new pharmacological tools for the study of K+ channels. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential of the microbiome to be manipulated therapeutically is being explored. The gut microbiome is also a dynamic system, and the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the host, diet, and the environment. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. We find that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, and that these fungi are a promising source of natural products for therapeutic use.

Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the lifespan of humans. The hemoglobin levels in the blood are controlled by the expression of the globin genes. In this study, we show that the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway has a downstream element, the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1), which is expressed in the erythroid lineage. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 can reprogram the hemoglobin expression in human erythroid cells toward a more fetal-like pattern. This is achieved by a reduction of the adult hemoglobin genes and an increase of the fetal hemoglobin gene. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we found that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis contributes to ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells. Finally, we show that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These findings provide a rationale for the development of combination therapies that target the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway and ferroptosis induction in cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). These drugs are associated with a higher risk of heart failure than other antihypertensive drugs. Our study shows that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our findings provide a mechanism for the action of LCCBs and suggest that the use of these drugs should be limited in patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not been effective in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the creation of early-seral ecosystems has not been effective in increasing the area of early-seral forests. These findings underscore the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The design strategy presented here is a promising tool for the development of new antibiotics. (Show more)

We introduce a new architecture for deep convolutional neural networks that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures. The proposed architecture is based on a simple set of operations that are automatically adapted to the problem at hand. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results for several segmentation problems with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures. The proposed architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice, and is expected to be useful for other problems in computer vision.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice is associated with a decline in sleep duration and quality, with important consequences for health. The mechanisms behind this decline are not fully understood, but it is likely that the short-wavelength–enriched light emitted by these devices is a major contributor. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device suppresses melatonin and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

We show that the 187Os/188Os ratios of magnetic grains and bulk sediment from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of osmium in these samples. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the spherules and their leachates are often low, but Os in these objects is likely terrestrially derived. The role of CTLA-4 in the regulation of immune responses is well established, but the impact of CTLA-4 on the development of autoimmunity in the adult is not known. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in the adult, but not in the congenital setting. We also show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in both the central and the peripheral compartment.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of these genes in their genomes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). APOE isoform is also associated with differential risk for AD. APOE is also a major protein of astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system. Here, we show that APOE isoform regulates the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also show that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in astrocytes, which may be a consequence of APOE4-dependent decrease in the rate of synapse pruning. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a molecular basis for the differential risk of APOE4 for AD. They also provide a molecular basis for the differential risk of APOE4 for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the last layer of the Earth. It is a key to understanding the evolution of the Earth. However, it is difficult to study the inner core because it is deep inside the Earth. In this study, we use a persistent embryo method and molecular dynamics simulations to study the nucleation of the inner core. We find that the nucleation of the inner core is a two-step process. The first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase, which is a metastable phase. The second step is the nucleation of the hcp phase from the bcc phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well documented, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common features of marijuana abuse.

Language is the only known cognitive skill that evolved in isolation in other species. Thus, understanding the human language system is a key challenge in cognitive science. Here, we show that the most accurate deep learning models for natural language processing also outperform humans and state-of-the-art machine translation models on a key task of the language system, the prediction of upcoming words. We discuss the implications of these results for the nature of the language system, the nature of language processing computations, and the nature of human and nonhuman brains.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability of DL is not a fundamental problem, but rather a consequence of the lack of theoretical understanding of the relationship between stability and the ability to compute a neural network. We develop a classification theory for neural networks, which provides a necessary and sufficient condition for the existence of algorithms that can compute a neural network with a given accuracy. We prove that the instability of DL is a consequence of the lack of theoretical understanding of the relationship between stability and the ability to compute a neural network. We also introduce a new algorithm, which we prove to be stable and numerically verify to be fast.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a scientific scandal. The scientific community has been slow to recognize the many ways in which the pandemic is a product of the scientific and political response to it. This article is a call to action for the scientific community to acknowledge the role of science in the pandemic, to learn from the mistakes of the past, and to work toward a more responsible and evidence-based future.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which infects the peripheral nerves, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a reactional disease known as lepromatous leprosy. Here we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is the first genome sequence of a leprosy bacterium. We find that the two leprosy bacteria have retained many of the same functions, despite their ancient separation, and that they are remarkably conserved.

Entanglement and entropy are the two key resources for quantum information processing. They are also the two key quantities that are not conserved in time in the presence of interactions. Therefore, they are the two key quantities that are not conserved in time in the presence of interactions. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is the natural limit for interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency. To combat the pandemic, a vaccine is needed. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain. The vaccine candidate is highly attenuated, has a short incubation period, and is protective in a relevant animal model. The vaccine candidate is easy to manufacture and can be stored at 2–8 °C. These features, coupled with its potential use in mass vaccination programs, support its potential use in the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Plague is a disease with a long history of outbreaks and pandemics. It is caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis and can be transmitted by multiple transmission pathways, including rodent, flea, and droplet vectors. In this study, we propose a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or droplet transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also provides a framework for studying the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of other diseases.

The evolution of brain size has been used as a proxy for the evolution of brain power. However, this approach is biased by the fact that brains are bigger in bigger animals. Here, we show that the evolution of brain power in amniotes is better understood by looking at the number of neurons in the brain. We show that the evolution of brain power is characterized by four major shifts in the number of neurons in the brain. These shifts are associated with the evolution of complex behaviors in birds and mammals.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been the subject of intense investigation. However, the function of TRAP1 in normal cells is less clear. Here we show that TRAP1 is required for the metabolic switch from oxidative phosphorylation to aerobic glycolysis and glucose suppression in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. We also show that TRAP1 regulates mitochondrial c-Src, which is a key regulator of invasiveness. These data suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in the disassembly of actin filaments. It does so by severing filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is not known. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binds to filaments and that filament tension has no effect on this process. However, we also find that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We propose that this torque dramatically enhances severing, which is critical to the function of ADF in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genetic history of Madagascar. It also provides a reference for the genetic diversity of the island and the Indian Ocean region. It will be useful for the study of human evolution and migration. It will also be useful for the conservation of the genetic diversity of the island. (Show more)

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media platforms.

The ribosome is a key component of the protein synthesis machinery. It is a large, multisubunit complex that scans the messenger RNA (mRNA) to determine the amino acid sequence of the nascent polypeptide. The ribosome also has the ability to read the mRNA sequence and decode the codons into amino acids. Here, we show that the presence of a single modification in the mRNA can have a profound effect on the ribosome’s ability to decode the mRNA sequence. Our work suggests that the presence of a modification in the mRNA can alter the rate of translation and the rate at which the ribosome reads the mRNA sequence. These findings have implications for our understanding of the ribosome and its role in protein synthesis. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and time use. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

The common cold is the most common disease in the world, and the virus responsible, rhinovirus, is the most common cause of this disease. Despite the prevalence of rhinovirus, the mechanisms that allow the virus to replicate in the nasal cavity, where the temperature is cooler than the core body temperature, are not well understood. Here, we show that the temperature at which the virus replicates is dependent on the host cell antiviral response, which is more efficient at the nasal cavity temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (Show more)

Here we show that the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface-adhesion system to sense the mechanical activity of its surface-adhesion system. This system is used to promote the attachment of the bacteria to a surface, and is also used to regulate the bacterial response to the surface. This is an example of how bacteria can use their surface-adhesion system to sense the mechanical activity of their surface-adhesion system, and how this can be used to regulate the bacterial response to the surface. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which reveals that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the spread of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in the United States. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study highlights the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the role of animals in the spread of the virus. (Show more)

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global health crisis. The disease is believed to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau protein in the brain, but the role of the immune system in AD is not well understood. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type in the brain, are also involved in the immune response. We demonstrate that neurons are the source of inflammatory factors, which are important for the development of the AD-like pathology. Our findings provide a new perspective on the pathogenesis of AD and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the understanding of the evolution of this species. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the details are important for understanding the role of the protein in the cell. Here we show that the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, proceeds through distinct steps. The first step is a fast compaction of the unfolded protein into a polyglobular state. The second step is a slow formation of a native-like folding intermediate. The intermediate is the obligatory pathway on the way to the native state. The intermediate is composed of segments that are distant in the sequence but adjacent in the native protein. The intermediate is a major target for mutations that slow the folding. The intermediate is a major target for mutations that slow the folding.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not fully understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4-capped RNAs is also the enzyme that removes the cap from other transcripts. This enzyme, which is normally inactive in the presence of disulfide stress, is activated by the presence of Np4, and it is this enzyme that is responsible for the removal of the cap from Np4-capped transcripts. This work provides a mechanism for how Np4 can regulate gene expression in bacteria.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune system is activated in response to infection, it can become dysfunctional, leading to the development of a proinflammatory state that is associated with poor clinical outcomes. We demonstrate that arginine, an essential amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be used as a therapeutic strategy to improve the immune response in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also show that the biomass of humans has increased by a factor of 100 since the beginning of the Holocene. Our results highlight the importance of the human impact on the biomass of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems can be tuned to exhibit critical behavior. SOC systems are characterized by the presence of a power-law distribution of activity levels, and a critical slowing down of activity fluctuations. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for quantum applications, but its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that strain engineering can be used to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond. We show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be made direct, by applying strain. We also show that the bandgap can be made indirect by applying tensile strain. These findings can be used to tailor the properties of diamond for quantum applications.

The role of plant immune system in the defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the molecular mechanisms of action of the plant immune peptides are not fully understood. Here, we report the mode of action of a unique, structurally defined, antifungal peptide, NCR044, which is expressed in the nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula. We show that this peptide is a potent fungicide and has a unique mode of action. It binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in germlings of the plant fungal pathogen Botrytis cinerea, which leads to the disruption of the fungal cell wall, loss of turgor, and death. This work provides insights into the mode of action of a class of plant immune peptides and paves the way for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This would be a significant advance in the management of plant fungal diseases. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the male–female interface is dynamic and that the female reproductive tract is a source of proteins that support sperm viability. Our research provides a foundation for understanding the molecular basis of sperm–FRT interactions and provides a resource for future studies of the molecular basis of sperm–FRT interactions.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease (VWD), a disorder of the blood that is caused by mutations in VWF. The mechanism also explains the effects of mutations in VWD, which are often dramatic.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been shown to influence health. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study. This study is a major step forward in the field, providing a comprehensive resource for the human virome. We find that viruses are associated with a wide range of diseases, and that the virome is more complex than previously thought. This resource will be useful to the research community for years to come.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. We demonstrate the capability of this technique by conducting a case study over Beijing. The results show that the ACI process is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. This study provides a new way to study the ACI process. It is expected to be a significant contribution to the ACI research.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for understanding the origin and evolution of life. Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide insights into the mechanism of K+ channel gating and the regulation of K+ channel activity. They also provide a possible explanation for the BK channel’s unique properties, such as its normal closing and the absence of C-type inactivation. Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people each year, and there is an urgent need to develop new treatments. One of the key steps in the parasite’s life cycle is invasion of the red blood cell (RBC), which is the site of parasite replication. Here, we show that the malaria parasite binds to the surface of the RBC, which leads to changes in the physical properties of the cell. These changes are critical for invasion, suggesting that the parasite is priming the cell surface to facilitate invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that it is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This could lead to the development of new strategies to prevent invasion. (Show more)

Diamond is a promising material for quantum applications, but its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by strain engineering, which can be used to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond. We also show that diamond can be transformed into graphite, which is a promising material for quantum applications, by strain engineering. Our findings can be used to tailor the properties of diamond for quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the mechanisms of dry air-induced disease pathology and suggest that low humidity may be a potential target for influenza vaccine and antiviral development. This study also provides a platform for the development of new strategies to mitigate the impact of dry air on influenza disease. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described in terms of a tree of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Activity in superior temporal and inferior frontal cortices was consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. The canonical Wnt pathway is a major pathway in development and homeostasis. It is also a major target of cancer. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its function is to convert signals at the plasma membrane to signals that inhibit the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and specific gene activation. We show here that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently, and this difference is used to control the responsiveness of the pathway in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain involved in the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes rapid vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the midbrain. This circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, suggesting that it is not involved in the normal regulation of feeding. Thus, this circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the primary nutrient limiting plant growth, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen cycle in agriculture is therefore a key goal of synthetic biology. Here, we demonstrate the first step toward this goal, the development of a system that allows control of the nitrogen cycle in a plant–bacterial association. This system is based on the ability of plants to produce a bacterial signal, rhizopine, and allows the control of bacterial gene expression in association with the plant. We show that this system can be used to control the expression of genes involved in nitrogen metabolism in a plant–bacterial association. Although the nitrogenase activity in this system was suboptimal, this work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is a step toward the development of a synthetic nitrogen cycle in agriculture. (Show more)

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the program’s short duration. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense for all animals. However, the evolution of the auditory organs of animals has been constrained by the organism’s body size. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body-sized eardrum. Instead, the spider uses the web it spins to sense the acoustic waves that approach the spider. We demonstrate that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna, which is more sensitive to acoustic waves than the acoustic responsivity of the entire spider. This study provides a unique example of how the outsourcing of hearing can be achieved in animals and opens up new possibilities for studying the evolution of acoustic sensing and for designing novel acoustic flow detectors.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The global distribution of vaccines is uneven, and many LMICs have limited access to vaccines. We engineered a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that is well-suited for large-volume microbial manufacturing. This engineered RBD variant exhibits high-affinity binding to ACE2, and antibodies raised against the engineered protein exhibited heterotypic binding to the RBD from two recently reported SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern (VOCs). Presentation of the engineered RBD on a designed VLP also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD variant may be a promising candidate for a subunit vaccine. This engineered RBD variant may provide a cost-effective, scalable, and safe vaccine for LMICs. (Show more)

The role of the ALK/ALKALS receptor–ligand pair in the development of neural crest-derived tissues is unknown. Here, we show that zebrafish ALKALS are involved in the regulation of neural crest development. We demonstrate that zebrafish ALKALS are able to activate the ALK/ALKALS receptor–ligand pair in vitro and in vivo. Our results provide evidence that zebrafish ALKALS are involved in the regulation of neural crest development and suggest that this receptor–ligand pair is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues in vertebrates.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a key event in its evolution. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Eurasian Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, which is a critical time period for understanding the spread of plague across Eurasia. Our results show that plague underwent a period of rapid evolution and dispersal during this time, and that the emergence of the flea-adapted form of plague occurred in Iberia. These data provide a more complete picture of the formative years of plague and its relationship to its host, the flea. They also provide a resource for future studies of plague’s evolution and ecology. (Show more)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Donald Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election.

The management of agricultural lands has a profound impact on the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has led to the release of massive amounts of carbon to the atmosphere. In this study, we show that the management of agricultural lands can be used to mitigate this release of carbon. We demonstrate that the management of grasslands and the integration of livestock can be used to sequester carbon in the soil. Our results highlight the potential of grasslands to mitigate climate change and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural practices.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 wildlife viruses with the greatest spillover potential, which included SARS-CoV-2. We hope that this work will inform the development of strategies to prevent future spillover events and mitigate the impact of future viral threats.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a mechanism for the production of this pigment in plants. This work provides a molecular framework for understanding the evolution of the red color of nectar and the role of alkaloids in this process.

We present a case study of the genetic landscape of a population in southern Germany during the Early Medieval period. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly of northern and central European origin, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, spike mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. Thus, MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases

The ability to rapidly detect and characterize pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to the early detection and response to emerging and reemerging pathogens. We demonstrate the feasibility of using metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to detect a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a resource-scarce setting. We show that mNGS can be used to identify pathogens responsible for undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of mNGS in resource-scarce settings and the potential for mNGS to be used as a tool for pathogen surveillance.

The human genome is replicated in a highly coordinated and complex process. The lagging strand of the genome is replicated by DNA polymerases that are tethered to the DNA via a sliding clamp. The sliding clamp is composed of two subunits, proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) and a clamp loader. The clamp loader is responsible for the assembly of the sliding clamp. In this study, we developed a unique kinetic assay to measure the stability of the human clamp loader. We found that the human clamp loader is not as stable as previously thought. This finding has profound implications for the replication of the lagging strand of the human genome.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In this paper, we describe the first demonstration of the ability of RNA to replicate itself.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

COVID-19 is a severe disease with high mortality. The treatment is mainly supportive. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is a monoclonal antibody against interleukin 6, can reduce mortality and improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic to cells. In fungi, the maintenance of copper homeostasis is accomplished through a variety of mechanisms, including the production of metal-binding natural products. In this study, we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a metal-binding isocyanide natural product. This is the first report of a fungal metal-binding natural product. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings have implications for our understanding of fungal physiology and interactions with other microbes. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature, low-pressure polymorph of SiO2 that is associated with silicic volcanism. Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agricultural crops. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that this change is driven by the geographic distribution of the species that are most vulnerable to frost damage. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a subset of CD4+ T cells that play a central role in the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to these cells are not well understood. Here, we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both the transcription factors T-bet and the Stat4 transcription factor. Moreover, we show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease mechanism is unknown. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays an important role in the transmission of pathogens to humans. We now show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota. This perturbation of the gut microbiota is critical for the ability of Anaplasma to colonize the tick. Mechanistically, the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen can use a host protein to influence the gut microbiota and enhance transmission to a vector. This knowledge will be useful for the development of strategies to control the spread of human pathogens. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of life. However, the origin of the modern avian body plan is still controversial. Here, we describe a new basal pygostylian from the Early Cretaceous of China, which adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. In some species, the color of their tissues and bones is green, which is a color that is not found in nature. This phenomenon is called chlorosis. We show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times in anurans, and that it is caused by the presence of a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a compound that is the main pigment of green plants. These proteins are most similar to human antiproteases, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The ability of breast cancer cells to form cancer stem cells (CSCs) is a major obstacle to the treatment of this disease. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces breast cancer cells to produce a protein, AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates the mRNA of pluripotency factor NANOG, which is a marker of CSCs. This results in increased levels of NANOG mRNA and protein, and the CSC phenotype. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We analyzed 265 parchment samples from 293 manuscripts, including 72 pocket Bibles. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, and identified the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript. These results suggest that the production of parchment was not dependent on the use of abortive or newborn animals, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this extinction event is critical for understanding the causes and mechanisms of extinction and recovery. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery of the end-Permian biota. The age model is based on the age of the Meishan volcanic ash bed, which caps the global Permian-Triassic boundary. The age of the ash bed is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Ma, respectively.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. It is essential for maintaining homeostasis and preventing the entry of pathogens. However, intestinal inflammation is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis and attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) signaling in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs). Our results suggest that RORα/HDAC3-mediated NF-κB signaling is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. This study provides a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the host receptor, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), and to compare the structure of the spike in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation. We find that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the host cell. This work provides a detailed structural understanding of the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure of the spike and may inform the development of vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. The chemical behavior of atoms is a fundamental property of matter. It is the basis of chemistry, and it is the key to understanding the origin of the diversity of the chemical world. In this work, we show that the chemical behavior of atoms can be quantified, and that the chemical behavior of atoms can be predicted.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, but the impact of this on the global carbon cycle is poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography can reduce the frequency of wildfires, which can have a large impact on the carbon cycle. Our results suggest that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. This highlights the importance of active management of fire regimes, which can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the dynamics of a symbiont population in a specific symbiotic organ. This glycan is provided by the host animal only at night, when the organ is colonized by immune cells that release the glycan into the symbiotic organ. We also show that the catabolism of this glycan is required for the maintenance of the symbiont population, and that this catabolism is specific to the night. This glycan may therefore be used by hosts to regulate the activities of their symbiotic microbes.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to analyze the narratives of violent deaths reported to the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We find that the narratives contain topics that are not captured by the structured variables of the system. We also find that the topics are gendered, and that the gender bias of the topics is consistent with known patterns in suicide and homicide. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to a wide range of domains, and can be extended to other types of data. It can also be used to identify the gender bias of topics.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. It is generally assumed that the bacterium Yersinia pestis was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. However, this assumption is based on a single hypothesis, which has not been tested. We show that the climate conditions in Asia and Europe were similar in the years preceding the arrival of the plague in Europe, and that the first plague outbreaks in Europe were preceded by climate conditions that were favorable for the introduction of the bacterium into European harbors. Our results provide evidence for repeated reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from Asia, with a delay of 15 y. This suggests that the Black Death was not introduced into Europe by a single event, but rather by multiple introductions.

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is a devastating disease affecting a wide range of species of sea stars (asteroids) in the Northeast Pacific. The disease is caused by a densovirus, which is transmitted by the sea stars’ feeding arms. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is transmitted by the feeding arms. We also show that the virus is present in the past and is still present today. This study provides a better understanding of the dynamics of the disease and the mechanisms of its spread. It also provides a better understanding of the history of the disease and the role of the virus in the evolution of the disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor prognosis. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies for AML, ideally targeting the disease-initiating cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML.
